marketNews.title: Other things that are currently hot that you need to know...
marketNews.content: 1. US President, Donald Trump, said on Tuesday (22/4) that he has no intention of firing Federal Reserve Chair, Jerome Powell. Trump stated that he only wants to see Powell be more proactive in the 'idea of lowering interest rates.' Rumors that Trump planned to fire Powell emerged after the Director of the US National Economic Council, Kevin Hassett, said last week that Trump was studying whether he was able to fire Powell. 2. Bank Indonesia on Wednesday (23/4) decided to maintain the BI Rate at 5.75%, with the deposit facility and lending facility also maintained at 5% and 6.5% respectively. This decision is in line with consensus expectations. 3. Bank Indonesia noted that credit growth slowed to +9.16% YoY in 1Q25 (vs. 2M25: +10.3% YoY), below Bank Indonesia's 2025 target range of +11-13% YoY. Based on use, investment credit grew +13.36% YoY, consumption credit +9.32% YoY, and working capital +6.51% YoY. Meanwhile, Sharia financing in 1Q25 grew +9.18% YoY and MSME credit growth reached +1.95% YoY. 4. The IMF cut its global growth projections for 2025 and 2026 to +2.8% YoY and +3% YoY respectively, following the escalation of the global trade war. These projections are lower compared to the outlook in January 2025, where the IMF projected global economic growth of +3.3% YoY for both 2025 and 2026. The IMF also cut its projection for Indonesia's economic growth in 2025 and 2026 to +4.7% YoY, lower than the January 2025 outlook which projected growth of +5.1% YoY for both years. 5. US President, Donald Trump, said on Tuesday (22/4) that the US will set its own terms if China does not agree to a trade deal, although he did not elaborate further. Trump also said he would be very kind in negotiations with the Chinese government. Trump added that Chinese import tariffs would drop significantly after the deal is finalized, but not to zero. 6. The Malaysian Palm Oil Board said on Tuesday (22/4) that CPO demand from China and India is expected to increase because CPO prices currently at 3,900 ringgit per ton are relatively reasonable compared to competing commodities. China and India are major importers of CPO. On Wednesday (23/4), CPO traders in India also told Reuters that India began increasing CPO purchases as their prices are currently cheaper than soybean oil. 7. Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, claimed on Wednesday (23/4) that Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt will replace LG Energy Solution as the strategic investor in the electric vehicle battery project with the Indonesian government. Previously, the consortium led by LG announced its withdrawal from the project early this week. Bahlil claimed there would be no change to the basic plan of the project, with groundbreaking planned for the end of 2025. Zhejiang Huayou Cobalt has not yet responded to Bahlil's claim. 8. National Economic Council member, Agus Puji Prasetyono, said on Tuesday (22/4) that the first nuclear power plant (PLTN) in Indonesia is designed to have an initial capacity of 2x250 MW. Priority locations for construction are spread across several provinces: West Kalimantan, Bangka Belitung, Southeast Sulawesi, and Halmahera Island. The PLTN project itself will be controlled directly by the government, with international cooperation prioritized in the form of government-to-government arrangements. Last week, Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources, Bahlil Lahadalia, claimed that the government targets the first PLTN to begin operating in 2030 or 2032. 9. Tesla CEO, Elon Musk, said on Tuesday (22/4) that he will begin reducing his time at the US Government Efficiency Department (DOGE) starting in May 2025. Musk's statement came amid worsening operational performance for Tesla in 1Q25, where car sales dropped -20% YoY and net profit plummeted -71% YoY. BBC reported that Musk's involvement in politics has caused protests and boycotts of Tesla cars.

tickerNews.title: BBCA 1Q25 Net Profit +9.8% YoY, In Line with Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Central Asia ($BBCA) recorded a net profit of 14.1 trillion rupiah in 1Q25 (+9.8% YoY, +2.8% QoQ), relatively in line with expectations (24% of consensus 2025F estimates). Net profit growth was driven by solid operational performance, with: 1) Net Interest Income (NII) rising +7% YoY; and 2) opex contained, growing only +3% YoY, resulting in Pre-provision Operating Profit (PPOP) growing +10% YoY. On the other hand, asset quality deteriorated and is a concern for us. 1. Credit Growth Starting to Moderate. In headline terms, total credit still grew strongly by +13% YoY in 1Q25 (vs. 2024: +14% YoY). However, BBCA management explained that this result was driven by a surge in short-term money market loans. Excluding these loans, total credit only grew around +10% YoY, starting to approach management's 2025 guidance in the range of +6-8% YoY. In addition to credit growth, solid CASA growth (+8% YoY) also contributed to NII growth of +7% YoY with NIM at the level of 5.8%, in line with guidance. The CASA Ratio is now at 82.9% as of 1Q25, increasing both annually and quarterly. BBCA management stated that the company will tend to be more cautious in disbursing financing, implying that credit growth will moderate until the end of 2025. The slowdown in credit growth is expected to be compensated by an increase in loan yield, where BBCA management sees room for loan repricing. 2. Asset Quality Deterioration. NPL rose to 2% in 1Q25 (vs. 1Q24: 1.9%, 4Q24: 1.8%) and LAR increased quarterly to 6% (vs. 1Q24: 6.6%, 4Q24: 5.3%). Cost of credit (CoC) was recorded at 0.5% (vs. 1Q24: 0.4%, 4Q24: -0.1%), higher than management's 2025 guidance of 0.3%. BBCA management explained that the NPL increase is related to debtors in the textile sector, while the LAR increase is due to the restructuring of debtors in the mineral sector. BBCA management explained that this restructuring will only be short-term, lasting a few months, and will be completed in 2Q25. Looking overall, BBCA management said that the asset quality condition is still quite manageable, so they have not decided to revise the CoC guidance upwards for this year. 3. Plans for Collaboration with BP Tapera in the People's Housing Program. Regarding reports of BBCA's plan to be involved in the people's housing program, BBCA management explained that the execution of this collaboration will be carried out carefully and gradually. From a business perspective, BBCA management said this program has a good margin, considering subsidies from BP Tapera. However, BBCA will be selective in participating, focusing only on housing that has a good ecosystem/infrastructure. Management is also open to a bullion bank program, although it still requires thorough calculation given the volatility of gold prices as the underlying asset and the necessary technical readiness. Key Takeaway. Overall, we assess BBCA's performance in 1Q25 is still solid. Matters that investors need to watch closely include: 1) the success of loan repricing to compensate for the slowdown in credit growth; and 2) asset quality developments amidst high uncertainty conditions. BBCA management stated that direct exposure to sectors/businesses exporting to the US is about 2% of total credit.

tickerNews.title: LPPF Projects 1Q25 Net Profit Above Rp600 Billion
tickerNews.content: 1. $LPPF: Matahari Department Store said in a clarification to the IDX that the company projects a proforma net profit in 1Q25 exceeding 600 billion rupiah, equivalent to 72% of 2024 net profit and 89% of 2023 net profit. This projection implies net profit growth in 1Q25 of at least +84% YoY and +192% QoQ. LPPF's clarification came after the company planned to distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends worth approximately 677.5 billion rupiah at the end of April 2025, even though cash and cash equivalents at the end of 2024 only reached 399 billion rupiah. LPPF also stated that after distributing dividends, the company is confident it can maintain positive equity in 2Q25 in line with its performance. LPPF itself projects a positive proforma net profit in 2Q25, although it did not provide further details (vs. 2Q24 net profit: 300 billion rupiah).

tickerNews.title: MEDC plans share buyback up to 240 million shares with allocation up to 408 billion rupiah
tickerNews.content: 2. $MEDC: Medco Energi Internasional plans to buy back up to 240 million (0.95%) shares with a fund allocation of up to 408 billion rupiah from June 4, 2025, to June 3, 2026. This plan will be discussed at the GMS on June 3, 2025. Previously, MEDC had announced it would buy back up to 407 million (1.62%) shares with a fund allocation of up to 820 billion rupiah from March 26 to June 25, 2025, following the relaxation of buyback rules provided by OJK to support capital market stability. Both corporate actions imply a maximum fund allocation for MEDC share buyback reaching approximately 1.2 trillion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: SMGR Cement Sales Volume Decreased in March 2025
tickerNews.content: 4. $SMGR: Semen Indonesia recorded cement sales volume of 2.6 million tons in March 2025 (-17% YoY, -14% MoM), in line with the shift of the Eid al-Fitr holiday. This result brought SMGR cement sales volume for 1Q25 to 8.6 million tons (-6.6% YoY). The decline in cement sales volume in March 2025 was caused by weakening sales from Indonesian facilities to 2.5 million tons (-17% YoY, -16% MoM). In terms of product segmentation, bulk cement sales contributed 30.6% of total sales in March 2025 (vs. Feb 2025: 28%) and 28.5% during 1Q25.

tickerNews.title: KEJU Shareholders Approve 2024 Dividend of IDR 73.12 Billion and Plan New Factory Construction
tickerNews.content: 5. $KEJU: Mulia Boga Raya shareholders approved the plan to distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends amounting to 73.12 billion rupiah or 13 rupiah per share, equivalent to a 49.8% dividend payout ratio and indicating a 2.2% dividend yield as of Wednesday (23/4). The cum-date in the regular and negotiation market has not been announced, while payment is scheduled for May 23, 2025. KEJU Director, Jeffry Halim, said that the company targets sales growth of double digits throughout 2025, supported by the launch of various new products starting from 2Q25 as well as market expansion and strengthening of distribution channels. KEJU also plans to build a new production facility worth approximately 691.6 billion rupiah in Sumedang, West Java, with a production capacity of 45,249 tons per year. The construction project will commence in 2025 and is targeted for completion in 2028. For context, KEJU currently only has 1 factory with a production capacity of 33,064 tons per year.

tickerNews.title: HEAL Shareholders Approve 2024 Dividend of IDR 161 Billion
tickerNews.content: 6. $HEAL: Medikaloka Hermina shareholders approved the plan to distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends amounting to 161 billion rupiah or 10.5 rupiah per share, equivalent to a 30.1% dividend payout ratio and indicating a 1% dividend yield as of Wednesday (23/4). The cum-date and payment date have not been announced.

tickerNews.title: BFIN signs credit facility agreement of IDR 2.8 trillion from BBCA
tickerNews.content: 7. $BFIN: BFI Finance Indonesia signed a credit facility agreement of 2.8 trillion rupiah from Bank Central Asia ($BBCA). The facility consists of an installment loan 7 worth 2 trillion rupiah with a 3-year tenor intended for working capital, and an extension of a multi-facility credit facility of 800 billion rupiah.

tickerNews.title: BNLI 1Q25 Net Profit IDR 789 Billion, Pressed by Provisions
tickerNews.content: 8. $BNLI: Bank Permata recorded a net profit of 789 billion rupiah in 1Q25 (-2.3% YoY, +1% QoQ), pressured by provisioning expenses rising to 628 billion rupiah (+36% YoY, +88% QoQ) amidst Pre-provision Operating Profit which recorded growth (+9.2% YoY, +23% QoQ). On the top-line, Net Interest Income (NII) was relatively stable at 2.5 trillion rupiah (+1.6% YoY, -3.2% QoQ), with Net Interest Margin (NIM) decreasing to 4.16% (vs. 2024: 4.34%, 1Q24: 4.37%). Meanwhile, financing growth (including Sharia) slowed to +6% YoY (vs. 2024: +8.9% YoY, 1Q24: +13.6% YoY).

tickerNews.title: TLDN Signs Agreement to Acquire Palm Oil Plantation Company for IDR 160-210 Billion
tickerNews.content: 9. $TLDN: Teladan Prima Agro signed an agreement to acquire all shares of the crude palm oil plantation company, PT Cipta Davia Mandiri, with a transaction value of approximately 160-210 billion rupiah. Kontan reported that PT Cipta Davia Mandiri manages approximately 3,100 hectares of oil palm plantations, so the total planted area owned by TLDN will increase to approximately 63,500 hectares after this acquisition is completed.

tickerNews.title: MFIN Plans to Distribute 2024 Dividends of IDR 310 Billion and Bonus Shares
tickerNews.content: 10. $MFIN: Mandala Multifinance plans to distribute 2024 fiscal year dividends amounting to 310 billion rupiah or 116 rupiah per share, equivalent to a 60% dividend payout ratio and indicating a 3.4% dividend yield as of Wednesday (23/4). The cum-date in the regular and negotiation market is April 28, 2025, while payment is on May 22, 2025. MFIN also plans to distribute bonus shares with a ratio of 1,000:867.8 on May 22, 2025, where the cum-date in the regular and negotiation market is April 28, 2025.

tickerNews.title: BALI plans a private placement of up to ~393 million new shares
tickerNews.content: 11. $BALI: Bali Towerindo Sentra plans to conduct a private placement of up to ~393 million (10%) new shares with a dilution effect of up to 9.09%. The exercise price and prospective investors have not been announced, while the fund proceeds are intended for early repayment of part/all of the company's debt and capital expenditure. This plan will be discussed at the GMSLB on April 25, 2025.
